title: Sending Email - The basics more details and a full example
A typical email has three main components:

inline_content.Text: A typical email has three main components:

title: A recipient (represented as an email address)

inline_content.Text: A recipient (represented as an email address)

title: Sending mail in PHP can be as simple as calling the built-in function
mail()
c
mail()
c

takes up to five parameters but the first three are all that is required to send an email (although the four parameters is commonly used as will be demonstrated below). The first three parameters are:

inline_content.Text: Sending mail in PHP can be as simple as calling the built-in function

takes up to five parameters but the first three are all that is required to send an email (although the four parameters is commonly used as will be demonstrated below). The first three parameters are:

title: The body of the email (string) (e.g. the content of the email)

inline_content.Text: The body of the email (string) (e.g. the content of the email)

title: A minimal example would resemble the following code:

inline_content.Text: A minimal example would resemble the following code:

title: mail('recipient@example.com', 'Email Subject', 'This is the email message body');

content_resolved.code: mail('recipient@example.com', 'Email Subject', 'This is the email message body');

title: The simple example above works well in limited circumstances such as hardcoding an email alert for an internal system. However, it is common to place the data passed as the parameters for
mail()
c
in variables to make the code cleaner and easier to manage (for example, dynamically building an email from a form submission).

inline_content.Text: The simple example above works well in limited circumstances such as hardcoding an email alert for an internal system. However, it is common to place the data passed as the parameters for
in variables to make the code cleaner and easier to manage (for example, dynamically building an email from a form submission).

title: Additionally,
mail()
c
accepts a fourth parameter which allows you to have additional mail headers sent with your email. These headers can allow you to set:

inline_content.Text: accepts a fourth parameter which allows you to have additional mail headers sent with your email. These headers can allow you to set:

title: the
From
c
name and email address the user will see

inline_content.Text: name and email address the user will see

title: the
Reply-To
c
email address the user’s response will be sent to

inline_content.Text: email address the user’s response will be sent to

title: additional non-standards headers like
X-Mailer
c
which can tell the recipient this email was sent via PHP

inline_content.Text: which can tell the recipient this email was sent via PHP

title: The optional fifth parameter can be used to pass additional flags as command line options to the program configured to be used when sending mail, as defined by the
sendmail_path
c
configuration setting. For example, this can be used to set the envelope sender address when using sendmail/postfix with the
-f
c
sendmail option.

inline_content.Text: The optional fifth parameter can be used to pass additional flags as command line options to the program configured to be used when sending mail, as defined by the

title: Although using
mail()
c
can be pretty reliable, it is by no means guaranteed that an email will be sent when
mail()
c
is called. To see if there is a potential error when sending your email, you should capture the return value from
mail()
c
TRUE
c
will be returned if the mail was successfully accepted for delivery. Otherwise, you will receive
FALSE

title: NOTE
b
: Although
mail()
c
may return
TRUE
c
, it does
not
i
mean the email was sent or that the email will be received by the recipient. It only indicates the mail was successfully handed over to your system’s mail system successfully.

inline_content.Text: mean the email was sent or that the email will be received by the recipient. It only indicates the mail was successfully handed over to your system’s mail system successfully.
